G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action is brought under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, including but not limited to G.L. c. 186, § 14 (covenant of quiet enjoyment).

G.L. c. 186.proposition: Defendant Steven Thompson is an individual who, on information and belief, owns, operates, manages, and/or controls the residential premises located at 123 Maple Street, Worcester, Massachusetts 01603 (the “Premises”) and is Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 3.proposition: The Worcester District Court (Housing Court Department – Central Division) has subject matter jurisdiction over this residential landlord–tenant dispute pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 1, 3, because this action involves claims arising out of a residential rental agreement and alleged violations of rights and duties relating to the condition and use of residential premises.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because the Premises are located in Worcester, Worcester County, Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred in this county.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because the Premises are located in Worcester, Worcester County, Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred in this county.

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.raw_text: Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.
Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been the owner, lessor, or person in control of the Premises and is responsible for maintaining the Apartment and building in compliance with applicable law, including the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., and for ensuring Plaintiff’s covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

105 C.M.R. 410.550.proposition: Under 105 C.M.R. 410.550 and related State Sanitary Code provisions, the owner of a dwelling is responsible for maintaining the dwelling free from rodent infestation and for providing adequate extermination services, particularly in multi-unit buildings.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: An award of pre- and post-judgment interest as allowed by law under G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Under *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102–04, and *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. at 285–86, persistent and serious conditions within a tenant’s living space that are not timely and adequately corrected by the landlord can amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment entitling the tenant to damages.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion directly applies the Simon v. Solomon quiet-enjoyment framework to persistent, serious conditions affecting tenants’ use of their homes and common areas. It holds that if the landlord’s failure to act (here, to address pervasive criminal activity) permits a condition that seriously interferes with the tenancy, that can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, entitling tenants to relief. Although this case involves external criminal activity rather than physical defects, it clearly affirms that ongoing, serious conditions not adequately remedied by the landlord can amount to a compensable quiet-enjoyment breach.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … [T]he plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: The natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s failure to sufficiently address the rodent infestation was that Plaintiff would continue to endure rodent activity and mouse droppings in her kitchen, adversely affecting her health, safety, and comfort, and substantially interfering with her use of the Apartment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The case is about noise from a lounge, not rodents, but it articulates the broader principle that a landlord’s breach of quiet enjoyment can be found where a harmful condition is the “natural and probable consequence” of what the landlord did or failed to do, substantially interfering with habitability. That general rule supports using the “natural and probable consequence” framework to argue that a landlord’s failure to address a rodent infestation foreseeably results in continued rodent activity and substantial interference with health, safety, and use of the premises, even though the specific facts differ.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did… they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover her actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses when a violation of the lead paint statute constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and whether attorney’s fees are available in that context. It does not set out or apply the remedial formula of § 14 (actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees). The case ultimately vacates an attorney’s fee award and never articulates the specific measure of damages quoted in the proposition, so it does not support that proposition.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiffs then moved for attorney’s fees pursuant to G. L. c. 186, § 14, repeating their claim that the violation of the lead paint statute constituted a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14. The judge allowed the request and awarded attorney’s fees in the amount $63,705. … The award of attorney’s fees under G. L. c. 186, §. 14, is vacated. … Accordingly, the case is remanded to the Superior Court for entry of a new judgment on count two of the complaint in favor of the landlords.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102–04, and *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. at 285–86, persistent and serious conditions within a tenant’s living space that are not timely and adequately corrected by the landlord can amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment entitling the tenant to damages.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, habitable conditions—here, repeated flooding with water and sewage—can constitute an interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and supports damages, including for personal (emotional) injury. The court explains that ‘quiet enjoyment’ covers serious interferences with the tenancy, rejects a requirement of malicious intent, and affirms liability where the landlord’s reckless failure to correct persistent, serious conditions in the apartment impaired the tenant’s use and enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute…. Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 326 Mass. 3.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that serious and ongoing conditions affecting the habitability of a dwelling, including unsanitary or unsafe conditions, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord, after notice, fails to take reasonable steps to remedy them.
*Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 326 Mass. 3.support_reasoning: The case is a criminal prosecution for armed robbery and larceny of an automobile; it does not involve landlord-tenant law, habitability, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Nothing in the opinion discusses dwelling conditions, unsanitary or unsafe premises, or a landlord’s duty to repair after notice. It therefore cannot serve as authority for the stated proposition about Massachusetts law on breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 326 Mass. 3.relevant_excerpt: The defendant was tried and convicted upon an indictment charging him and one Kelly with armed robbery, and upon another indictment charging him with the larceny of an automobile. The only assignments of error argued by him are to the admission of certain articles in evidence and to the denial of his motions for directed verdicts of not guilty.

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that serious and ongoing conditions affecting the habitability of a dwelling, including unsanitary or unsafe conditions, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord, after notice, fails to take reasonable steps to remedy them.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses State Sanitary Code violations and awards damages for breach of the warranty of habitability, but it does not analyze or even mention the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court treats the conditions as relevant to habitability and rent abatement, not as interference with quiet enjoyment, and there is no holding that such conditions constitute a breach of the covenant when not remedied after notice. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific quiet enjoyment proposition stated.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs. … Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability…”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have long held that serious and ongoing conditions affecting the habitability of a dwelling, including unsanitary or unsafe conditions, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord, after notice, fails to take reasonable steps to remedy them.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that failure to provide heat, a serious condition affecting habitability governed by the State Sanitary Code, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 when the landlord fails to furnish it. While the opinion focuses specifically on lack of heat rather than a broad range of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, it treats that habitability defect as impairing the premises and amounting to a quiet enjoyment violation, which is consistent with the proposition’s general statement. The “after notice” element is implicit rather than expressly discussed, so the fit is strong but not perfect.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750[B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that sanitary code violations are evidence of uninhabitable conditions that can support claims under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and related doctrines.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly ties the warranty of habitability to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and states that a dwelling with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. It further treats such code noncompliance as triggering rent abatement and other tenant remedies, making code violations evidence of uninhabitable conditions. Although the case focuses on warranty/abatement rather than G.L. c. 186, § 14 specifically, its reasoning clearly supports using sanitary code violations as evidence of uninhabitability under related doctrines.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The State Sanitary Code, not such usage, provides the proper yardstick for measuring the landlord’s conduct. The Hemingway court removed the landlord’s duties under the Code from the realm of private ordering. Those duties cannot be waived, bargained away, or qualified by customary practice.”

*South Boston Elderly Residences, Inc. v.raw_text: *South Boston Elderly Residences, Inc. v. Moynahan*, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 455 (2017)
*South Boston Elderly Residences, Inc. v.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that sanitary code violations are evidence of uninhabitable conditions that can support claims under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and related doctrines.

*Santiago v. Commonwealth*, 428 Mass. 38.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that sanitary code violations are evidence of uninhabitable conditions that can support claims under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and related doctrines.
*Santiago v. Commonwealth*, 428 Mass. 38.case_name: First Federal Savings & Loan Ass'n of Galion v. Napoleon
*Santiago v. Commonwealth*, 428 Mass. 38.support_reasoning: The opinion in Santiago v. Commonwealth (actually a UFCA fraudulent conveyance case involving mortgage debt and insolvency) does not discuss landlord-tenant law, habitability, the State Sanitary Code, or G.L. c. 186, § 14. Its holding concerns how to define insolvency under the Uniform Fraudulent Conveyance Act and burden of proof issues, not conditions of uninhabitability or sanitary code violations. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the claimed proposition about sanitary code violations supporting G.L. c. 186, § 14 claims.
*Santiago v. Commonwealth*, 428 Mass. 38.relevant_excerpt: The purpose of the UFCA is to preserve a debtor’s assets so that creditors may look to them in the event that the debtor ceases payments or is declared bankrupt. See Jorden v. Ball, 357 Mass. 468 (1970); Blumenthal v. Blumenthal, 303 Mass. 275 (1939). Although the debtor may continue to deal with his assets in ordinary course, he may not give them away and thereby put them beyond the reach of creditors — which is precisely what the debtor did in this case.
